Authors:
John D Hall, Karolina Fucikova, Chien Lo, Louise A. Lewis,
Kenneth G. Karol
Title:
An assessment of proposed DNA barcodes in freshwater green
algae.
Keywords:
DNA barcode, green algae, Charophyceae, Chlorophyceae,
Zygnematophyceae, 18S, COI, ITS, rbcL, tufA, UPA
Abstract:
The development of DNA barcodes for green algae would aid
in their accurate and rapid identification. This is particularly
important for the green algae because in many genera structural
characters are few or difficult to observe. In this study we test the
utility of several DNA barcode loci in seven distantly related species
groups of charophytes and chlorophytes. The ITS and COI markers were the
most variable, although COI was least applicable because it was
successfully amplified and sequenced in only one test genus. Both rbcL
and tufA were moderately variable, although tufA may pose challenges in
some lineages where the gene is encoded in the nucleus. The 18S and UPA
were the least variable loci tested. Of the markers tested, ITS, rbcL
and tufA are the most promising for use as DNA barcodes. However, none
of the loci tested were ideal for use across all tested lineages of
green algae because of taxon-specific applicability and because none of
the markers could distinguish closely related species in all species
groups tested.
